Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative proposal: Faculty and Undergraduate Research Student Teams (FURST)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Faculty and Undergraduate Research Student Teams (FURST) program brings together small research groups comprised of undergraduate students and faculty from primarily undergraduate institutions (PUI) in order to provide them with a year-long research experience. The program also provides a one month long intensive summer immersion for its participants at an established summer REU site at Fresno State. FURST students get an opportunity to participate in professional workshops, presentations and academic discussions along with the REU students, whereas FURST faculty can take advantage of an on-site, in-person research collaboration with their peers within the FURST program. The program's main goal is to foster both student and faculty research at PUIs, with the specific goal of producing student and faculty authored publications, as well as presentations. The program is designed to be inclusive and accessible to teams from institutions with varying research focus and support, in order to mitigate cultural changes at institutions which may not consider research a quintessential component of higher education.

FURST students will be working on open problems in mathematics under the guidance of their faculty mentors. Research topics include community detection problems in networks, expanding the framework and analysis of the cop and robber game, the use of coarse Ricci curvature in data analysis and interpolation problems, the study and solution of the non-linear Riccati-Ermakov equation, as well as other non-linear dispersive partial differential equations. Strengthening their background in the selected research topic through readings and lecture at their home institutions will prepare FURST students to engage in research at the same speed as the REU students during the immersion phase. Students will be expected to submit the end product of their research for publication in a peer reviewed journal. FURST faculty will engage in solving open problems in their area of research while building collaborations with faculty at other institutions. Faculty are also expected to produce publishable work as a result of participating in the program. In accordance with the stated goals, the program will improve access to research for students at PUIs, where such opportunities are typically limited. It will also (re)-energize faculty at PUIs so that they remain active in research. By doing so, FURST will help transform the research culture at the participating institutions, especially since the bulk of the research activities will take place at FURST teams' home institutions. While FURST student participants will learn skills through the program that are invaluable in graduate school and in the scientific workplace, the program will broadly impact the students at the involved PUIs by demonstrating to them (through student talks and presentations) that research can be part of the undergraduate educational experience. Finally, through the immersion in an active REU site, FURST students will gain exposure to the workings of an REU program, and will be able to make better informed choices about applying to REU as a potential next step in their academic development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Faculty and Undergraduate Research Student Teams (FURST) program aims to involve faculty and students at primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs) in collaborative mathematics research. The main goals of the program are to (1) foster research collaborations between junior faculty at PUIs, to (2) involve such faculty in undergraduate research at their home institutions, and to (3) increase student access to research at institutions with limited or no research opportunities.

The California State University East Bay (CSUEB) FURST program has been implemented as a collaborative research program among undergraduate students and junior faculty, where each faculty participant selected a number of undergraduate students to form a research team and participated in collaborative research projects with other FURST faculty at CSUEB. Exceptionally, FURST teams joined the Fresno State REU research group for a one month immersion phase, during which FURST students were integrated into all of the REU activities, while FURST faculty had a four week period for intensive, on-site and in-person research collaboration. The CSUEB FURST teams have completed both the students' and the faculty's research projects during the entire project period.

The FURST program has provided opportunities for (1) collaborative research among junior faculty at PUIs to achieve pertinent career goals in research, (2) a year-long, faculty mentored undergraduate research experience for students at PUIs, and (3) a think-tank like summer immersion experience for each member of the FURST teams at the Fresno State REU site.

Intellectual Merit:

FURST students worked in teams under the guidance of their faculty mentors on open problems in pure and applied mathematics. Strengthening their background in the selected research topics through readings and seminars at CSUEB can prepare FURST students to engage in research at the same speed as the REU students during the immersion phase. While at the Fresno State REU site, FURST students gave weekly oral presentations, and participated in workshops offered by the REU site, including those on how to read and write research papers, and on the difficulties one may encounter while conducting research. Our FURST students submitted the end product of their research for publication in peer-reviewed journals and conferences. FURST faculty engaged in solving open problems in their area of research while building collaborations with faculty at other institutions, as well as produced publishable work as a result of participating in the program.

Broader Impacts:

The FURST program has improved access to research for students at PUIs, where such opportunities are typically limited. It also re-energized faculty at PUIs and helped them remain active in research. As a result, FURST program transformed the research culture at CSUEB, since the majority of the research activities took place at CSUEB during the project period. While FURST students learned important research skills through the program that are invaluable in graduate school and in the scientific workplace, the program broadly impacted the students at CSUEB by demonstrating to them through student talks and presentations that research can be part of the undergraduate educational experience. Finally, through the immersion phase in an active REU site, FURST students gained exposure to an REU program, and were able to make better-informed choices about applying to REU as a potential next step in their academic development.
